title: 'Local Furniture Industry Collapsing'
text:
21 September 2015 17:39 CET 'Local Furniture Industry Collapsing' By Daily Guide Mr. Richard Abbey Jnr speaking at the opening ceremony of the fair 
Richard Abbey, the Executive Director of Xodus Communications, an events management, public relations and marketing firm, says the local furniture industry is on the brink of collapse. 
Mr Abbey stressed the need for government and other stakeholders to take urgent steps to save the sector from complete collapse. 
He made this known at the sixth Furniture and DÃ©cor Fair (FURNIDEC) held on Thursday at the Accra National Theater. 
The fair, organized annually by Xodus Communications Limited in collaboration with the Forestry Commission, is designed to offer ample business opportunities to players in the local furniture sector to help promote made in Ghana goods. 
Companies that took part in the fair included Latex Foam, Tekura Handicraft, Woodeck Company, Furnart Ghana Limited, Saabrown Company Limited, Yenok Wood Products, Kings Furniture Company Limited, Unique Wood and General works, among others. 
Chief Director of the Ministry of Trade and Industry, Baeka Dawarnoba, in a statement, admitted that the local furniture sector was rapidly collapsing. 
The Executive Director of Xodus Communications blamed the development on the influx of foreign furniture products on the Ghanaian market, as well as certain existing unfair trade policies of the European Union (EU) and Government of Ghana. 
Procurement Act to be amended According to him, government was looking at new policies to bring relief to stakeholders in the furniture sub-sector, as well as other local industries that are facing challenges as a result of stiff competition from foreign firms in the country. 
He said government was in the process of reviewing the current Procurement Act of Ghana to make it mandatory for all state agencies, ministries and departments, as well as big companies operating in the country to source a chunk of all their goods and services locally. 
It is unfair for state agencies to use Ghanaian taxpayers' money to purchase goods from abroad when indeed such items are being manufactured by the citizenry in the country, he indicated. 
He further noted that the ongoing revision of the procurement law was also aimed at reducing the nation's foreign exchange deficit on imported goods. 
Director of Operations, Timber Industry Development and Division (TIDD), Forestry Commission, Henry Coleman, for his part, said government must develop the capacity of local furniture manufacturers. 
He also urged local manufacturers to increase their brand values in order to compete favourably on the market. 
By Melvin Tarlue
